narrative=MP, Liam Bull, was last seen leaving his after-school program. His grandmother reported him missing when he failed to arrive home. Witnesses suggested that Liam might have boarded a ferry, potentially heading towards Kirkcaldy. Reports also indicated his potential involvement in minor criminal activities around Ladybank Road, Pitlessie. Eventually, police traced him to 7 Dorran Square, with no harm and circumstances clarified.

narrative=Liam Bull was last seen leaving his home on 23 Haddow Grove, Burntisland, without his phone, indicating he left in a hurry. His grandmother mentioned Liam's excitement about potentially boarding a ferry, hinting at his possible travel intentions. Joshua Clark, a close family friend, mentioned seeing Liam near Lochies Road, Burntisland, but lost track of him. Searches extended towards Rosyth, leading to the discovery of Liam at 23 Norval Place by the police. narrative=Liam Bull, a 10-year-old with no disabilities, was reported missing from a fast food restaurant on Limekilns Road, Dunfermline. His grandmother recalled he left his phone at home, which was unusual for him. He had planned to visit Seaforth Place, Burntisland, where Charlotte Mills last saw him playing. Concerns grew when he didn't return home. Aaron Holland, a family acquaintance, remembered seeing Liam near Hawkcraig Road, Aberdour. After a widespread search, he was safely found by a member of the public at Pettycur Bay, Kinghorn. His absence was linked to curiosity-driven exploration, leading to a low final risk level upon return.

narrative=Liam Bull, a 10-year-old from Newcastle-upon-Tyne, went missing after leaving home without his phone. His father, Alan Bull, grew concerned when Liam hadn't returned from his usual outing. It was noted that Liam often enjoyed exploring the nearby national park. A search party began combing through the park after it became apparent that Liam hadn't informed anyone of his whereabouts. Alan and Liam's friend, Tom Smith, provided helpful details about Liam's love for adventure, which guided the search efforts. Fortunately, Liam was traced by park staff three days later, safe and sound but slightly disoriented at an address in Kinghorn, beyond his familiar territory.

narrative=Liam Bull was last seen at a national park after leaving 23 Norval Place, Rosyth. His phone was left at home, and there was information suggesting he was involved in criminal activity. Additionally, there were reports of a possible ferry boarding linked to his disappearance. Witnesses indicated he visited his grandmother prior to going missing. Authorities suspect the incident may have involved domestic violence-related circumstances. Liam was later traced and safely recovered by police.

narrative=Liam Bull, aged 11, was reported missing from his home at 23 Haddow Grove, Burntisland. Prior to his disappearance, Liam had visited a national park with his friend, Naomi. Inquiries led to 1 Findlay Crescent, Rosyth, known for domestic violence-related incidents, but yielded no results. Eventually traced by police, Liam was found safe at 39 The Temple, Lower Largo. The reasons behind his disappearance remain unclear, yet the circumstances tie loosely back to the concerning behavioral patterns observed prior.

narrative=Liam Bull, an 11-year-old from Burntisland, was last seen at his family home. Concerns arose when he was unaccounted for following a family outing to a national park known for its serene environment but proximity to a domestic violence-related shelter. Despite initial fears, friends and family coordinated a search, ultimately finding Liam safe with his family in Rosyth. Investigators believe he may have wandered off amidst family tensions.

narrative=Liam Bull was reported missing after he did not return home from a reportedly innocent outing at a nearby national park. Known for occasionally leaving his phone at home, this time Liam had left it behind deliberately, raising concerns after his absence extended longer than usual. Friends noted Liam's recent fascination with exploring secluded areas. An acquaintance, Tom Smith, mentioned seeing Liam heading towards the skate park from the main entrance of the national park. The police found Liam safe at a summer camp, sorting through the implications of his actions.

narrative=Liam Bull, a 12-year-old, was last seen near a fast food restaurant on Langlands Road, St Andrews. However, there were reports of him being spotted at 1 Parkside Square, Rosyth, which raised alarm due to its association with unfavorable activities. The situation ended with Liam being safely located, and it was determined that the initial high-risk assessment was due to miscommunication and worry over his past behaviors.
